Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Mechanisms of Hydration Kinetics and Property Development in Activated Slag and Fly Ash Multiphase Sustainable Binder Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate the hydration mechanism of activated ground granulated blast furnace slag and fly ash for designing binder systems with improved performance. The mechanism of dissolution of slag and fly ash in alkaline medium, product phase nucleation, growth and diffusion, and interdependence of hydration of individual phases will be determined using different characterization techniques. Methods for modifying reaction kinetics of the activated binders, by influencing the type and rate of product phase nucleation will also be explored. Analytical hydration models based on nucleation and growth principles, and chemical kinetics will be developed for activated binders considering the multi-phase, multi-stage nature of hydration in these systems. The educational plan in this project is strongly integrated with research component through research integrated broader curriculum development, development of K-12 outreach program integrating proposed research, and diversity initiative through minority student recruitments.

The research is to understand the fundamental mechanism of the reaction kinetics of slag and fly ash activated systems, and the results will promote alternative sustainable construction materials with better performance, lower CO2 foot print and lower embodied energy. It is also a crucial step toward engineering this revolutionary concrete for increased acceptance in the field. The hydration model, incorporating the effect of complexities due to multi-phase/multi-stage nature of the activated systems, will be a new development. Preparing civil engineering students as tomorrow?s technological leaders is envisioned through the proposed advancement in civil engineering curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Reserach Component Outcome:  Concrete is one of the most widely used construction materials and ordinary portland cement (OPC) is the binding component in the concrete. Therefore, CO2 emission from cement production is substantial, and contributes significantly to global warming. Inventing low CO2 binders that can serve as a feasible alternative to OPC is considered as a potential solution among concrete research community.  Alkali activated concrete (AAC), prepared by mixing aluminosilicate containing materials such as fly ash and slag with a strong alkali solution, is such an alternative binder material that has shown great promise in preliminary studies. Fly ash or slag dissolves in alkaline environment and forms an inorganic polymeric product with good binding properties, like cement. However, the lack of a scientific understanding of the fundamental hydration mechanisms of these materials has hindered the development of these transformative materials into practically feasible concrete products.

The goal of this CAREER proposal was to advance the scientific understanding of the cement free binder systems by performing a detailed experimental investigation of alkali activated slag and fly ash cement free binders. The major accomplishment of the project are; 1)  characterized hydration mechanisms in terms of the dissolution of slag and fly ash in the alkaline medium, product phase nucleation, gelation, polymerization, diffusion, interdependence of the hydration of individual phases, and the evolution of microstructure, morphology and composition of the product phases, 2) established the dependence of the degree of reaction and the early age properties of the binder on the chemical composition of source materials, the dosage of activator, and processing conditions, 3) conceptualized a novel method for modifying the reaction kinetics by influencing the type and rate of product phase nucleation using nano/submicron-particles, 4) investigated the hydration behavior of systems with high volumes of slag/fly ash with OPC and small percentage of alkali or nano particles (multi-phase systems), 5) developed cement free concretes with designed compressive strengths of 20 – 100 MPa and evaluated their feasibility successfully by characterizing its engineering properties such as compressive strength, tensile strength, modulus of elasticity, stress strain behavior, drying shrinkage, and chloride permeability, 6) developed two computational models to simulate the reaction kinetics of the alkali activated systems based on Avrami nucleation and boundary nucleation theories.

 The scientific understanding gained from this study is expected to aid immensely in encouraging the field implementation of alkali activation technology. The better understanding of the hydration mechanisms could contribute to the development of optimal alkali activation systems. Similarly, the extensive performance data of the cement free concrete generated in this project could help designers to choose right materials for infrastructural application. The new method used to modify reaction kinetics may lead to the development of high performance alkali activated systems. Finally, the computational model developed in this study can serve as an excellent design tool for developing new material systems by predicting their reaction kinetics. This work produced fifteen peer reviewed journal and conference papers, four MS or PhD theses, and several national or international conference presentations.

Educational component outcome: The accomplishments in the education component of the proposal are,

(1)   Developed a co-operative and problem based learning curriculum for undergraduate and graduate students by introducing recent advancements in material science of concrete. As part of the curriculum, three courses were developed; cement chemistry, experimental method in cementitious material characterization, and materials science and engineering I. This new curriculum has helped to increase undergraduate involvement in research, even from majors outside civil engineering.

(2)   Developed a module for K-12 workshop outreach program by integrating a topic on sustainable material. The workshop was aimed to promote interest in high school girls in civil engineering. The first workshop module was delivered as a part of the Horizon program in the summer of 2014. A total of ninety-six girls attending 8th and 9th grades in various schools in New York State attended the intense training program.

(3)   Contributed to the diversity initiative through the recruitment of female and other minority students. Among four graduate students funded from this project, three were females and two of them were of African origin. Five female students conducted undergraduate research under this project with the aid of REU supplements. The project has also supported many graduate students; three students completed their MS degrees and a fourth student is expected to complete her PhD work in the fall of 2017. A total of nine undergraduate students gained research experience through REU supplement under this support.
